thread.title: NFL's chief of officials: 'We have to make that call'
thread.title_full: NFL's chief of officials: 'We have to make that call' - seattlepi.com

author: SCOTT SUNDE, SEATTLEPI.COM
title: NFL's chief of officials: 'We have to make that call'
text:
It's official.
The NFL blew one Monday night, giving the Seahawks a less-than-deserved win over the Detroit Lions.
The replay: Lions receiver Calvin Johnson appears headed for a go-ahead touchdown when Kam Chancellor punches the ball out of Johnson's hands at the goal line.
Photo: Elaine Thompson, AP Seattle Seahawks strong safety Kam Chancellor (31) knocks the ball loose from Detroit Lions wide receiver Calvin Johnson (81) in the second half of an NFL football game, Monday, Oct. 5, 2015, in Seattle. The fumble went out of bounds in the end zone and was ruled a touchback. The Seahawks beat the Lions 13-10. Seattle Seahawks strong safety Kam Chancellor (31) knocks the ball... As the ball bounced into the end zone, Seahawks linebacker K.J. Wright knocked it out of bounds.
Linebacker K.J. Wright of the Seattle Seahawks bats a loose ball out of the back of the end zone during the second half of a football game at CenturyLink Field on Oct. 5, 2015, in Seattle, Washington. The Seahawks won the game 13-10.
Linebacker K.J. Wright of the Seattle Seahawks bats a loose ball...
 The officials call a touchback. Seahawks get the ball on the 20. Game over.
Except batting the ball in the end zone is illegal. Dean Blandino, the NFL's vice president of officiating, says the penalty should have been called against Wright. The would have given the Lions the ball at the 1-yard line.
From NFL.com:
"You can't bat the ball in either direction in the end zone," Blandino told NFL Network Monday night. "K.J. Wright batted the ball. That is a foul for an illegal bat.
Blandino was asked directly if a penalty should have been called.
"Yeah, looking at the replay, it looks like a bat. It looks like he takes his right hand and bats it intentionally," Blandino said. "It's a foul. We have to make that call."
Wright later told The Seattle Times that he indeed batted the ball .
